## Your Turn 1

Run the code on the slide to make a graph. Pay strict attention to spelling, capitalization, and parentheses!

```{r}
#| label:create mpg scatterplot
ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                           y = hwy))
```

## Your Turn 3

Make a histogram of the `hwy` variable from `mpg`. Hint: do not supply a y variable.

```{r}
#| label: make a histogram
ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = hwy), 
                 fill = "light blue",
                 color = "black")

```

## Your Turn 4

Use the help page for `geom_histogram` to make the bins 2 units wide.

```{r}
#| label: change histogram bin-width

ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = hwy), 
                 binwidth = 2,
                 fill = "light blue",
                 color = "black")
```


## Your Turn 5

Add `color`, `size`, `alpha`, and `shape` aesthetics to your graph. Experiment.  

```{r}
#| label: add-color-size-alpha-shape-to-point
ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                           y = hwy,
                           color = class))+
  labs(x = "Engine Size Displacement",
       y = "Highway Mileage",
       color = "Class of Vehicle",
       title = "The bigger the engine the less mileage we get on the highway") +
  theme_light()
```
```{r}
#| label: add-color-size-alpha-shape-to-point
ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                           y = hwy,
                           size = class)) +
    labs(x = "Engine Size Displacement",
       y = "Highway Mileage",
       color = "Class of Vehicle",
       title = "The bigger the engine the less mileage we get on the highway") +
  theme_light()
```

## Help Me

What do `facet_grid()` and `facet_wrap()` do? 
(run the code, interpret, convince your group)

```{r}
#| label: add-label-help-me
# Makes a plot that the commands below will modify
q <- ggplot(mpg) + geom_point(aes(x = displ, y = hwy))

q + facet_grid(. ~ cyl)
q + facet_grid(drv ~ .)
q + facet_grid(drv ~ cyl)
q + facet_wrap(~ class)
```

# Take aways

You can use this starter code template to make thousands of graphs with **ggplot2**.

```{r}
#| label: template
#| eval: false
ggplot(data = <DATA>) +
  <GEOM_FUNCTION>(mapping = aes(<MAPPINGS>))
```
